section.title: Usage information
section.p: The keydef element is a convenience element. Anything that the keydef element does can also be accomplished with a topicref element. Attributes defaulted on the keydef element ensure that key definitions do not appear in the TOC, do not add extra links, and are not rendered as topics .

section.title: Specialization hierarchy
section.p: The keydef element is specialized from topicref. It is defined in the mapgroup-domain module.

sectiondiv.p: The following attributes are available on this element: , (with a narrowed definition of href, given below), (with a narrowed definition of processing-role, given below), , keyref, and the attributes defined below.

example.title: Example
example.p: The following code sample shows several different types of key definitions:
example.codeblock:
<map> <title>Possible keys for use in the DITA specification</title>
<keydef keys="dita-tc" scope="external" format="html" href="https://www.oasis-open.org/committees/tc_home.php?wg_abbrev=dita"> <topicmeta><linktext>DITA Technical Committee</linktext></topicmeta> </keydef>
<keydef keys="addressing" href="dita-addressing.dita"/>
<keydef keys="dita-version"> <topicmeta><linktext>2.0</linktext></topicmeta> </keydef>
</map>

ol.li: The first keydef defines a key that links to a Web page. It contains link text; it also specifies the necessary scope and format attributes, so that authors do not need to include them when they reference this key.
The second keydef defines a key for a local DITA topic about addressing in DITA; that topic is available to resolve link text.
The third keydef defines a text-only key that specifies the current DITA version number.
